<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/53  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 339, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Probability & Statistics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[772, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 383, 393, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 729, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 445, 88]]<|/det|>
For a set of 40 values of \(x\), it is found that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 101, 677, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma (x - k) = 836.0,\qquad \Sigma (x - k)^2 = 25410.8,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 288, 151]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 682, 183]]<|/det|>
Given that the mean of these 40 values is 124.0, find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 445, 143, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 445, 556, 463]]<|/det|>
Find the standard deviation of these 40 values of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 445, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A fair six-sided dice with faces labelled 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 is thrown repeatedly until a 3 is obtained. The number of throws taken is denoted by the random variable \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 144, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 277, 136]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X = 8)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 146, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 280, 320]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X < 9)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 303, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 551, 143, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 551, 784, 570]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that a 3 is obtained for the second time before the 6th throw.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 128, 828, 520]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 555, 146, 573]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 553, 920, 590]]<|/det|>
Use the graph to estimate how many people took between 4 and 7.5 minutes to complete the puzzle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 570, 917, 588]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 631, 89]]<|/det|>
Bag \(A\) contains 6 red marbles, 5 blue marbles and 1 green marble.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 504, 121]]<|/det|>
Bag \(B\) contains 5 red marbles and 3 blue marbles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 606, 152]]<|/det|>
A marble is chosen at random from bag \(A\) and placed in bag \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 487, 183]]<|/det|>
A marble is now chosen at random from bag \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 196, 146, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 848, 214]]<|/det|>
Draw a tree diagram to represent this information, giving the probability on each branch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 196, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 672, 89]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that both marbles chosen are the same colour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 89]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 440, 181, 458]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 440, 918, 476]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the marble chosen from bag \(A\) is blue, given that the marble chosen from bag \(B\) is blue.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 457, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A company sells bags of pasta. The masses of large bags of pasta are normally distributed with mean \(2.50\mathrm{kg}\) and standard deviation \(0.12\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 144, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 116, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the mass of pasta in a randomly chosen large bag is less than \(2.65\mathrm{kg}\). [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 420, 581, 440]]<|/det|>
A restaurant manager buys 160 of these large bags of pasta.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 144, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 920, 481]]<|/det|>
Find the number of bags for which you would expect the mass of pasta to be more than 1.65 standard deviations above the mean.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 463, 920, 482]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The masses of small bags of pasta sold by the company are normally distributed with mean \(\mu \mathrm{kg}\) and standard deviation \(\sigma \mathrm{kg}\). Tests show that \(77\%\) of these bags have masses greater than \(1.26\mathrm{kg}\), and \(44\%\) have masses less than \(1.35\mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 144, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 584, 153]]<|/det|>
Find, in either order, the value of \(\mu\) and the value of \(\sigma\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 902, 89]]<|/det|>
A set of friends consists of 7 men and 4 women. Three of the men are brothers: Ali, Ben and Charlie.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different arrangements of the 7 men in a line in which Ali and Ben do **not** stand next to each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 116, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
